results.title: Sentencing: the attainment of justice
results.creator_credit: Video Classroom, Geoff Russell and Peter Wiseman
results.brief_description: This video uncovers the often mysterious and unapproachable work of our senior lawmakers: the Attorney General, Magistrates and Judges who have the ultimate say over the severity of criminal sanctions. The program also goes inside the most notorious institutions such as HM Prison Pentridge, to give a unique and first-hand account into the sentencing and punishment of criminals.

results.title: Sentences, number line
results.brief_description: This film analyses word problems and associated number sentences. The number line is used to represent sets of admissible solutions under various operations. (Teacher education)

results.title: Sentences and paragraphs
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia and John Moss
results.brief_description: Celebrated author Margaret Clark discusses this most fundamental topic. Margaret reads from one of her books to illustrate key points. Also helping to provide interest in what can be perceived as a boring topic, is a leading Melbourne comedian and mime artist, Richard Jones. The program is funny, highly informative and definitely not boring! Suitable for Primary-Lower Secondary level students.

results.title: Senso daughters
results.creator_credit: Tenchijin Productions, Siglo Co, Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies and Noriko Sekiguchi
results.brief_description: Senso means “War”. “Senso daughters” is an account of the experience of Papua New Guinean and Japanese women in the South Pacific during World War II. A unique film in that it critically looks at the effect of the war not only on the indigenous culture but also on the Japanese people. Anti-war sentiment has never been tolerated within Japanese culture. For director, Noriko Sekiguchi, the film is very much a personal statement with a global message. Not only does the film critically question the war-time decisions of the late Emperor Hirohito, but it also makes public for the first time some startling information. The Japanese army took “comfort women” when they were occupying a new territory. The army prostitutes were conscripted from Korean and poor Japanese women and shipped to military bases in Rabaul.

results.title: Senso = Wanton Countess
results.creator_credit: Lux Film, Domenico Davanzati and Luchino Visconti
results.brief_description: Venice in 1866: Italy is soon to be freed of Austrian occupation. An older woman, a countess in a loveless marriage sacrifices her position, her honour and her principles for the love of a cynical Austrian officer. Livia’s full-blown romanticism drives her into isolation and near-madness and destroys Franz, the embittered romantic. Visconti’s special blend of the operatic and the realistic reflects his double focus as an aristocrat and Marxist on Italian history (the Risorgimento), continued in “The Leopard” in a subtler, more realistic mode. Cast includes Alida Valli, Farley Granger, Heinz Moog, Rina Morelli, and Massimo Girotti. Based on the novella by Camillo Boito. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Sensitivity to antibiotic injections
results.brief_description: The possibility of contamination by antibiotics during an injection given by ordinary methods is shown. New procedures for giving antibiotic injections without risk to the doctor or nurse are then demonstrated.

results.title: Senses and perception: links to the outside world
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Charles L. Finance and Giancarlo Lui
results.brief_description:
Shows differences in the process of sensory perception in higher animals and man. Emphasises that the senses are an animal’s link to its environment and are necessary for its survival.
Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Sense of home: getting older in a new country
results.creator_credit: Rhapsody Pictures, St George Migrant Resource Centre and Brian Rapsey
results.brief_description: Isis Hanna (Egyptian), Sammy Kwong (Chinese), Stavroula Pikros (Greek) are three elderly Australians. All emigrated to Australia, but at different times in Australia’s migration history. This documentary shares their stories and explores the effect of cultural difference and assimilation. They talk openly about aging in a foreign country ‘when home is no longer home’ and what they plan for the future. All subjects of the documentary have been part of a special program in Sydney at St. George Migrant Resource Centre designed for elderly migrants. Once a week each migrant group gets together to share a meal, socialise and tell stories.

results.title: Sense and sensibility (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mirage Enterprises, Columbia Pictures, Lindsay Doran and Ang Lee
results.brief_description: Ang Lee directs this well scripted, acted and beautifully photographed version of Jane Austen’s first novel. Emma Thompson, (who wrote the screenplay), and Kate Winslet are Elinor and Marianne. Elinor follows her head and Marianne is guided by her heart. Both sisters eventually find love but only after the usual complications. A star-studded cast includes Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman
